abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Zhejiang Urban
            Environment Project (ZUEP) for China were as follows:
            outcomes were satisfactory, the risk to development outcome
            was modest, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: the 'Tianziling method of landfill
            operations', developed by Hangzhou Solid Waste Company,
            Limited (HSWC), controls surface water runoff entry and
            ground water entering the landfill by introducing a High
            Density Polyethylene (HDPE) membrane cover instead of the
            generally used soil cover. This method reduces leach-ate
            generation and cost of land-filling, prevents odor, and
            increases the life of the landfill. Inclusion of industrial
            pollution action plan (IPCAP) in ZUEP addressed pollution
            control in a comprehensive manner, and included: a licensing
            and permit system for industry pollution control; database
            of pollution types and sources; industrial pollution
            monitoring program; water conservation; and catchment
            pollution control plan. The project experience in China has
            found that local communities, especially the poor, often
            have little appreciation for what tourists want or need.
            Services and souvenirs are generally of low quality and
            provide only small incomes. Related training provided by
            government entities/Associations often lags the most current
            approaches. In order to generate sustainable economic
            opportunities based on cultural heritage conservation and
            tourism, project planning and design should include specific
            attention to useful training, sound planning and realistic
            investments. Sustainable historic city revitalization
            requires a holistic approach, and the Bank has the unique
            ability to assemble multi-disciplinary task teams to design
            and supervise projects using this approach. The Bank is also
            distinct from most conservation and tourism organizations in
            its ability to set projects within a development and poverty
            reduction context.

repnme.cdata!:
Conserving the past as a foundation for the
            future : China-World Bank partnership on cultural heritage conservation

abstracts.cdata!:
The rich cultural heritage of China is
            an essential touchstone of its collective identity. The
            country's archaeological sites, historic architecture,
            expressive arts, cultural landscapes, and ethnic diversity
            also are treasured around the world. Despite their
            importance, China's cultural assets are under
            tremendous pressure due to the country's rapid
            development, particularly its rapid urbanization. Moreover,
            rising incomes and mobility have significantly increased
            domestic tourism, leading to the overdevelopment and
            deterioration of cultural heritage sites. However, many of
            China's government officials, conservationists, and
            community groups have recognized these threats and, over the
            past several decades, have worked tirelessly to protect
            their country's cultural heritage. Based on the 12
            projects developed under this partnership, this report
            presents an overview of the project approaches and
            experiences, takes stock of the challenges, extracts initial
            lessons learned, and identifies new directions and
            challenges ahead. The principal audience of the report is
            national, provincial, and municipal decision-makers engaged
            in conserving China's cultural heritage. This report
            also is intended to be of relevance to World Bank staff and
            those in the international community who wish to gain an
            overview of the projects conserving cultural heritage in
            China that have received World Bank financing.

docna.cdata!:
Conserving the past as a foundation for the
            future : China-World Bank partnership on cultural heritage conservation

Conserving the past as a foundation for the
            future : China-World Bank partnership on cultural heritage conservation

abstracts.cdata!:
The rich cultural heritage of China is
            an essential touchstone of its collective identity. The
            country's archaeological sites, historic architecture,
            expressive arts, cultural landscapes, and ethnic diversity
            also are treasured around the world. Despite their
            importance, China's cultural assets are under
            tremendous pressure due to the country's rapid
            development, particularly its rapid urbanization. Moreover,
            rising incomes and mobility have significantly increased
            domestic tourism, leading to the overdevelopment and
            deterioration of cultural heritage sites. However, many of
            China's government officials, conservationists, and
            community groups have recognized these threats and, over the
            past several decades, have worked tirelessly to protect
            their country's cultural heritage. Based on the 12
            projects developed under this partnership, this report
            presents an overview of the project approaches and
            experiences, takes stock of the challenges, extracts initial
            lessons learned, and identifies new directions and
            challenges ahead. The principal audience of the report is
            national, provincial, and municipal decision-makers engaged
            in conserving China's cultural heritage. This report
            also is intended to be of relevance to World Bank staff and
            those in the international community who wish to gain an
            overview of the projects conserving cultural heritage in
            China that have received World Bank financing.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Zhejiang Urban Environment Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Zhejiang Urban
            Environment Project for China is to establish an efficient
            modern urban management system so as to maintain urban
            ecological balance and improve environmental quality.
            Overall, while the potential positive environmental impacts
            resulting from the implementation of the Zhejiang Urban
            Environment Project are large, construction and operation
            impacts may induce environmental adversity, preventable if
            successfully mitigated as follows. Environmental
            strengthening is considered a critical component of the
            project, and a detailed technical assistance program is
            being developed to address such needs. This includes
            training in management, and operations, in a wide variety of
            disciplines. Water quality standards in river systems,
            lakes, and reservoirs should be raised by 5-10 percent
            points, while standards on the basis of functional zoning of
            lakes and reservoirs should be raised over 70 percent. Water
            quality indicators should be controlled in the offshore sea
            areas according to the functional zoning requirements, and
            improved year by year. By 2005, the discharge amounts of
            SO2, dusts - smoke, and industrial ashes - COD, NH3-N,
            industrial solid wastes, and other main pollutants should be
            ten percent less than those in 2000, while major
            environmental protection cities should meet a standard of
            100 percent in surface water quality. Similarly, centralized
            urban wastewater treatment rates should raise standards by
            45-60 percent, while urban domestic treatment rates (with no
            harmful effects) should meet a 90 percent acceptance
            standard. Public green surfaces should be above 8 square
            meters per capita in cities, planning to reach new green
            surface, and landscape coverage rates, by 30-35 percent.

10572388.trustfund:
TF026849-PHRD-CHINA: ZHEJIANG URBAN
            ENVIRONMENT PROJECT,TF026241-PHRD-ZHEJIANG URBAN ENVIRONMENT PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
China - Zhejiang Urban Environment Project
            : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Zhejiang Urban
            Environment Project for China is to establish an efficient
            modern urban management system so as to maintain urban
            ecological balance and improve environmental quality.
            Overall, while the potential positive environmental impacts
            resulting from the implementation of the Zhejiang Urban
            Environment Project are large, construction and operation
            impacts may induce environmental adversity, preventable if
            successfully mitigated as follows. Environmental
            strengthening is considered a critical component of the
            project, and a detailed technical assistance program is
            being developed to address such needs. This includes
            training in management, and operations, in a wide variety of
            disciplines. Water quality standards in river systems,
            lakes, and reservoirs should be raised by 5-10 percent
            points, while standards on the basis of functional zoning of
            lakes and reservoirs should be raised over 70 percent. Water
            quality indicators should be controlled in the offshore sea
            areas according to the functional zoning requirements, and
            improved year by year. By 2005, the discharge amounts of
            SO2, dusts - smoke, and industrial ashes - COD, NH3-N,
            industrial solid wastes, and other main pollutants should be
            ten percent less than those in 2000, while major
            environmental protection cities should meet a standard of
            100 percent in surface water quality. Similarly, centralized
            urban wastewater treatment rates should raise standards by
            45-60 percent, while urban domestic treatment rates (with no
            harmful effects) should meet a 90 percent acceptance
            standard. Public green surfaces should be above 8 square
            meters per capita in cities, planning to reach new green
            surface, and landscape coverage rates, by 30-35 percent.

10572449.trustfund:
TF026849-PHRD-CHINA: ZHEJIANG URBAN
            ENVIRONMENT PROJECT,TF026241-PHRD-ZHEJIANG URBAN ENVIRONMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
This project paper seeks the approval of
            the Executive Directors to introduce the following changes
            in the China Zhejiang Urban Environment Project (ZUEP): (i)
            the utilization of loan savings to support investments for
            the rehabilitation of the historic Yue Kingdom Conservation
            area in Shaoxing; and (ii) the increase of the disbursement
            percentage from 80 percent to 100 percent for works carried
            out in Shaoxing and paid by Shaoxing after December 1, 2007.
            The proposed new investments are in line with and will
            contribute toward meeting the original project development
            objective of redeveloping the historic inner city in
            Shaoxing. The overall project development objective is to
            enhance the efficiency and equity of waste management in the
            municipalities of Ningbo and Hangzhou, and to support the
            redevelopment of the historic inner city of Shaoxing and
            Cicheng, thereby facilitating the sustainable development of
            these cities and establishing a model for the conservation
            of cultural heritage in other Chinese cities.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Zhejiang Urban Environment Project
            : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
The Zhejiang Urban Environment for China
            will construct a ring road at the inner side of the moat,
            connecting the road net around the town and the internal
            road net; laying the sewer net in the central town area.
            This construction will have a profound meaning in terms of
            protecting old town's cultural feature, developing
            economic and tourist resources, decreasing environment
            pollution, improving living quality and promoting
            sustainable socioeconomic development. The resettlement
            policies will include cash compensation; offer or
            resettlement houses; offer of low rent houses for the poor.
            In cash compensation program, the compensation is calculated
            by the replacement price of the demolished house plus the
            land price. For each household, if the construction acreage
            of demolished old houses is within 250
